title: How ‘Stop the Steal’ Captured the American Right
abstract: The movement to reinstate President Trump has gone far beyond him — and now threatens the future of American elections.
byline: By Charles Homans and Mark Peterson

title: Which Elected Leaders Should Do More on Climate? Here’s What Americans Say.
abstract: Detailed survey data revealed that most Americans say Congress should do more to address global warming.
byline: By Mira Rojanasakul and Catrin Einhorn
org_facet: Yale Program on Climate Change Communication

title: ‘Late Show’ Staff Arrested at U.S. Capitol Complex Won’t Be Prosecuted
abstract: The Justice Department said it would not proceed with charges of unlawful entry against staff members from “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were arrested at a Capitol building last month.
des_facet: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: When members of the “Late Show” staff were detained at the U.S. Capitol complex, they had been filming a segment featuring Triumph the Insult Comic Dog, a puppet voiced by Robert Smigel.

title: What to Watch For in Tuesday’s Primary Elections in Maryland
abstract: There are close contests in the Democratic and Republican primaries for governor, and in a few House races as the dust settles from redistricting. But the winners could take days to be called.

title: Trump National Security Aide Expected to Testify at Jan. 6 Hearing
abstract: Matthew Pottinger, who resigned on the day of the Capitol riot, is expected to be among those at the prime-time session on Thursday, along with Sarah Matthews, a former deputy press secretary.

title: Doug Mastriano called climate change ‘pop science.’ That video, and others, vanished from his social media.

title: Democrats Navigate Nuanced Views on Abortion Among Black Voters
abstract: Faced with a streak of conservatism about abortion among some Black Americans, a vital constituency for President Biden, Democrats are framing the issue as part of a broader civil rights struggle.

title: Eight U.S. House Offices File for the Right to Unionize
abstract: The petitions are the first step for congressional aides to negotiate their working conditions with the same legal protections that other federal workers enjoy.

title: How Joe Manchin Left a Global Tax Deal in Limbo
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen’s signature achievement is in jeopardy if the United States cannot ratify the tax agreement that she brokered.
byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

multimedia.caption: Senator Joe Manchin III effectively scuttled the Biden administration’s tax agenda in Congress by saying he could not immediately support a climate, energy and tax package he had previously indicated he could support.

title: U.S. aid chief criticizes China’s ‘absence’ in a food crisis stoked by Russia’s invasion.
abstract: Samantha Power, the administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development, criticized China for hoarding fertilizer and grain while millions of people in East Africa face starvation.
org_facet: United States Agency for International Development

multimedia.caption: “Countries that have sat out this war must not sit out this global food crisis,” Samantha Power, the administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development, said in Washington on Monday.

title: Justice Jackson, a Former Law Clerk, Returns to a Transformed Supreme Court
abstract: In the 22 years since she worked for Justice Stephen G. Breyer, whom she replaced last month, the court has become polarized and predictably conservative.

title: They Had Miscarriages, and New Abortion Laws Obstructed Treatment
abstract: Surgical procedures and medication for miscarriages are identical to those for abortion, and some patients report delayed or denied miscarriage care because doctors and pharmacists fear running afoul of abortion bans.

multimedia.caption: Before Texas’s restrictive abortion law took effect, Amanda received a standard surgical procedure for a miscarriage. After the law, when she had another miscarriage, she said the same hospital declined to perform surgery and sent her home with instructions to return only if her bleeding was so excessive that it filled a diaper more than once an hour.
multimedia.copyright: Nancy Newberry for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Before Texas’s restrictive abortion law took effect, Amanda received a standard surgical procedure for a miscarriage. title: As the Planet Cooks, Climate Stalls as a Political Issue
abstract: Joe Manchin’s rejection of a compromise climate bill tells a familiar story: Voters and politicians put a higher premium on immediate issues, such as inflation and the economy, giving politicians a pass on global warming.
byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa

multimedia.caption: Phoenix had its hottest summer ever and two hottest months in its history in 2020. The temperature reached or exceeded 110 degrees on 50 days.

title: Little-Known Lawyer Pitched Trump on Extreme Plans to Subvert Election
abstract: The role of William J. Olson in advising the president in late 2020, which has not previously been disclosed, shows how fringe figures were influencing him at a critical time.
byline: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

title: Read William J. Olson’s Memo to Trump
abstract: William J. Olson, a right-wing lawyer, sent a memo in December 2020 to President Donald J. Trump on how to seek to overturn the election.

title: Unpredictable Maryland Governor’s Race Pits Old Guard vs. Upstarts
abstract: Will a deep-blue state elect another Republican governor to succeed Larry Hogan? Tuesday’s competitive primaries will signal where the race is headed.
